questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The area of a triangle with base $4 \text{ cm}$ and height $6 \text{ cm}$ is $24 \text{ cm}^2$.
questions.solution:
Answer: False

Justification:
Area of a triangle $= \frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}$
$= \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 6 = 12 \text{ cm}^2$.
The given area is $24 \text{ cm}^2$, which is incorrect.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The area of $\Delta ABC$ is $8 \text{ cm}^2$ in which $AB = AC = 4 \text{ cm}$ and $\angle A = 90^\circ$.
questions.solution:
Answer: True

Justification:
Since $\angle A = 90^\circ$, $\Delta ABC$ is a right-angled triangle with base $AB$ (or $AC$) and height $AC$ (or $AB$).
Area $= \frac{1}{2} \times AB \times AC$
$= \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 4 = 8 \text{ cm}^2$.
The statement is correct.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The area of the isosceles triangle is $\frac{5}{4}\sqrt{11} \text{ cm}^2$, if the perimeter is $11 \text{ cm}$ and the base is $5 \text{ cm}$.
questions.solution:
Answer: True

Justification:
Let the equal sides be $b$.
Perimeter $= 5 + b + b = 11 \Rightarrow 2b = 6 \Rightarrow b = 3 \text{ cm}$.
Sides are $a=5, b=3, c=3$.
Semi-perimeter $s = \frac{11}{2} \text{ cm}$.
Area $= \sqrt{s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)}$
$= \sqrt{\frac{11}{2}(\frac{11}{2}-5)(\frac{11}{2}-3)(\frac{11}{2}-3)}$
$= \sqrt{\frac{11}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{5}{2} \times \frac{5}{2}}$
$= \frac{5}{4}\sqrt{11} \text{ cm}^2$.
The statement is correct.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The area of the equilateral triangle is $20\sqrt{3} \text{ cm}^2$ whose each side is $8 \text{ cm}$.
questions.solution:
Answer: False

Justification:
Area of an equilateral triangle $= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (\text{side})^2$
$= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (8)^2 = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} \times 64 = 16\sqrt{3} \text{ cm}^2$.
The given area is $20\sqrt{3} \text{ cm}^2$, which is incorrect.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: If the side of a rhombus is $10 \text{ cm}$ and one diagonal is $16 \text{ cm}$, the area of the rhombus is $96 \text{ cm}^2$.
questions.solution:
Answer: True

Justification:
Diagonals of a rhombus bisect each other at $90^\circ$.
Let diagonals be $d_1 = 16$ and $d_2$. Half of $d_1$ is $8$.
Using Pythagoras theorem in one of the four triangles formed by diagonals:
$(\frac{d_2}{2})^2 + 8^2 = 10^2$
$(\frac{d_2}{2})^2 = 100 - 64 = 36 \Rightarrow \frac{d_2}{2} = 6 \Rightarrow d_2 = 12 \text{ cm}$.
Area of rhombus $= \frac{1}{2} \times d_1 \times d_2 = \frac{1}{2} \times 16 \times 12 = 96 \text{ cm}^2$.
The statement is correct.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The base and the corresponding altitude of a parallelogram are $10 \text{ cm}$ and $3.5 \text{ cm}$ respectively. The area of the parallelogram is $30 \text{ cm}^2$.
questions.solution:
Answer: False

Justification:
Area of a parallelogram $= \text{base} \times \text{altitude}$
$= 10 \times 3.5 = 35 \text{ cm}^2$.
The given area is $30 \text{ cm}^2$, which is incorrect.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The area of a regular hexagon of side '$a$' is the sum of the areas of the five equilateral triangles with side '$a$'.
questions.solution:
Answer: False

Justification:
A regular hexagon is divided into six equilateral triangles of side '$a$' by joining the centre to the vertices.
Therefore, the area of a regular hexagon is the sum of the areas of six equilateral triangles, not five.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The cost of leveling the ground in the form of a triangle having the sides $51 \text{ m}$, $37 \text{ m}$ and $20 \text{ m}$ at the rate of Rs $3$ per $\text{m}^2$ is Rs $918$.
questions.solution:
Answer: True

Justification:
Sides are $a=51, b=37, c=20$.
$s = \frac{51+37+20}{2} = \frac{108}{2} = 54 \text{ m}$.
Area $= \sqrt{54(54-51)(54-37)(54-20)}$
$= \sqrt{54 \times 3 \times 17 \times 34}$
$= \sqrt{(9 \times 6) \times 3 \times 17 \times (2 \times 17)}$
$= \sqrt{9 \times (6 \times 3 \times 2) \times 17^2}$
$= \sqrt{9 \times 36 \times 17^2}$
$= 3 \times 6 \times 17 = 306 \text{ m}^2$.
Cost $= 306 \times 3 = \text{Rs } 918$.
The statement is correct.

questions.question: Write True or False and justify your answer: The area of a triangle with sides $14 \text{ cm}$, $16 \text{ cm}$ and $26 \text{ cm}$ is the same as that of a parallelogram with base $28 \text{ cm}$ and height $16 \text{ cm}$.
questions.solution:
Answer: False

Justification:
Area of parallelogram $= 28 \times 16 = 448 \text{ cm}^2$.
For triangle: $s = \frac{14+16+26}{2} = \frac{56}{2} = 28 \text{ cm}$.
Area of triangle $= \sqrt{28(28-14)(28-16)(28-26)}$
$= \sqrt{28 \times 14 \times 12 \times 2}$
$= \sqrt{(14 \times 2) \times 14 \times (4 \times 3) \times 2}$
$= \sqrt{14^2 \times 2^2 \times 4 \times 3}$
$= 14 \times 2 \times 2 \sqrt{3} = 56\sqrt{3} \approx 97 \text{ cm}^2$.
Since $56\sqrt{3} \neq 448$, the statement is false.
